title.narrative: Financial Sector and Enterprise Recovery - Ukraine
WB Financial Sector and Enterprise Recovery - Ukraine

description.narrative:
Insatsen är en kortsiktig plan för policy dialog och kapacitetsutveckling för ukrainska myndigheter. Baserat på erfarenhet, pågående projekt och den ukrainska reformagendan har följande två komponenter valts ut:
- Finansiell sektor - Företagssektor
Insatsen består av teknisk assistans som syftar till att stärka ukrainska myndigheters kapacitet att formulera reformpaket. Det syftar även till att säkra den ukrainska banksektorn för ökad transparens och tillgång till krediter för små och medelstora företag för en fungerande marknad.

The proposal from the WB “Supporting Financial Sector and Enterprise Recovery has been developed in the light of the economic crisis that emerged as a result of the political conflict and the ensuing military conflict in the eastern part of Ukraine. This is an operational response to the new needs and transition opportunities and addresses the urgent needs as regards support for the design and implementation of policy reforms and institutional capacity building as well as investment support, all in agreement with the Ukrainian government and other public authorities. The programme offers short hand medium -term technical assistance (TA), mostly consisting of policy dialogue and institutional capacity building, to different Ukrainian actors.
The set-up of the agreement stipulates that this is a multi-donor trust fund, serving to support the financial sector and enterprise recovery during these harsh economic times. However, currently only Sweden is entering into agreement. It is a quick response focusing on technical assistance with two components: 1) Financial sector component and 2) Enterprise sector component. The immediate target groups include but are not limited to: • National Bank of Ukraine • Ministry of Finance of Ukraine • Financial institutions and associations • Market stakeholders, including business associations, consumer advocacy groups • Lawmakers
The proposal, being of the type of technical assistance, directs itself to the Ukrainian government and other actors linked to the sectors. Those who are directly affected by the intervention are among others different staff at the involved Ukrainian public authorities. Final beneficiaries from the activities will be the Ukrainian society and its people since the objective of the BETF is to help a more stable and transparent bank sector, reduce red tape and other obstacles linked to low productivity and thereby enabling the business climate, most probably leading to job creation.

description.narrative:
This contribution was originally intended to focus on two areas broadly:
1) supporting regulatory reform and innovation, and
2) supporting financial sector recovery.
As pillar 1 was somewhat delayed and pillar 2 progressing well it was decided to break of pillar 2 into a separate contribution for project management reasons and to facilitate disbursements. The World Bank (WB) was unable to re-distribute funding between the components as these pillars are set up as separate "sub" trust-funds in the WB system.
To resolve this issue the more successful work of pillar 2 was continued in a separate contribution - 11414 Financial Sector Recovery and Resilience Ukraine from 30-11-2017. As of this date, the contribution focused only on regulatory and innovation related issues while financial sector support continued in contribution 11414.
This allowed for more focused follow-up of a very technical are and allowed the contributions to proceed at a different pace (dictated mainly be the government reform agenda). A negative affect was that this contribution received somewhat less priority from the WB local office.
The lack of interest by Ukrainian counterparts in the further the innovation agenda, which was a focus for the contribution after 2018 was surprising. Despite certain positive momentum it is now clear in retrospect that this was not a priority for the government. For this reason, the decision was made not to continue this contribution, but rather to start potentially start with a new contribution should momentum develop.
Results
Pillar 1. Supporting regulatory reform and innovation. The World Bank supported the Governments reforms aimed at recovery and growth of the enterprise sector in Ukraine through project activities as specified in the Administrative Agreement focusing on de-regulation, enabling business environment, covering the National Quality Infrastructure assessment, State-owned Enterprise Reform agenda, and innovation policy reform. The main outputs of this pillar are:
(i) Assessment of innovation policies applied in various sectors, recommendations and suggestions of good approaches used in other countries to improve policies;
(ii) Assessment of the current status of the National Innovation System (NIS) in Ukraine - the report identifies concrete policies and reforms that could improve the innovation and entrepreneurship conditions in Ukraine in the short to medium term period;
(iii) Development of a set of recommendations to GoU for a roadmap to reform and restructure the NIS, to be further undertaken for implementation by the relevant Ukrainian stakeholders.
Pillar 2. Financial sector recovery. The technical assistance within the scope of the project was provided during one of the most severe banking crises in Ukraine and thus targeted such critical for crisis-management areas as strengthening banking supervision and deposit insurance system as well as activities aimed at forward-looking recovery of the system post-crisis.
The key outcomes and achievements of the project in the financial sector included:
i) strengthening banking supervision, shaping the assets quality reviewed and related party diagnostic of banks in order to show real assets quality, capital level and related party exposures;
ii) strengthening and enhancing the deposit guarantee system by shortening temporary administration, creation of back-up funding mechanism for the Deposit Guarantee Fund (DGF) and substantially strengthening the DGF toolkit and powers to recover assets; and
iii) creation of initial NPL workout instruments, in particular, multi-creditor restructuring framework called Ukraine Approach.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
